newsitem.title: BELGIUM: Nielsen to discontinue some practices in Europe.
newsitem.headline: Nielsen to discontinue some practices in Europe.

text.p: AC Nielsen, the world-wide market research firm, will stop what have been called unfair practices related to the collection of sales data in Europe, the European Commission said Tuesday.

The move was a victory for rival U.S. company, Information Resources Inc., which has been trying to dent Nielsen's worldwide leadership in the market for retail tracking services ever since it launched the first scanner to register purchases at supermarket checkout counters.
The Commission started an investigation in May into a complaint by Information Resources that Nielsen's practices were effectively stopping it from accessing sales data in Europe.

The EC said Tuesday it had dropped the probe after getting the assurance from Nielsen that it would no longer put an exclusivity clause in its contracts preventing retailers from providing data to its rivals.

Retail tracking services gather and process information on actual product sales, prices, promotions and other market data for the purpose of analysing the performance of specific products over a given period of time.
Such data were obtained manually until the introduction of scanners.

AC Nielsen is the world's leading provider of such services with 1995 revenues of $1.3 billion. Information Resources, the world's second largest market research company, gained a large share of the U.S. market after introducing its first scanner-based retail tracking service in 1986.
The Antitrust Division of the U.S. Department of Justice had also closed its own investigation into the case in view of the results achieved in Europe, the Commission said.
